description:
Create a bond between yourself and your Tea Dragon that grows as you progress through the seasons, creating memories to share forever.

Each player's deck represents their own Tea Dragon. From turn to turn, players will choose to draw a card, triggering effects and strengthening their position, or buy a card, improving their deck or scoring points. At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins!

Autumn Harvest: A Tea Dragon Society Game is a standalone game that can be combined  with The Tea Dragon Society Card Game and expanding gameplay to five players!

Zeal is a game of religious conquest in a 16th century type of setting. Each player represents a different religion/cult that is trying to spread across the globe.

Gameplay is simple but strategy is deep and luck is not a factor. Players, on their turns, can take one action (move pieces, produce more pieces, convert an area to their religion, or slaughter pieces).

Each player also has 4 miracle cards that they can use to their advantage (each god has its own unique set of 6 miracle cards to choose from).

Game can end in 2 ways:
If a player places 10 temple cubes/controls 10 areas on the board (8 in a 3p game), that player wins immediately.

If every area on the board has a temple on it, the game ends immediately. The player with the most temples on the board wins. If a 3 player game ends this way and 2 players are tied for most temples, remove the losing's players temples and the 2 players that were tied for first continue to play until one of them places 10 temples.

-description from designer

Battlelund is The Paper Wargame. 
It is accessible, adorable, and affordable. 
Battlelund is the charm and cute that everyone needs. It is made for everybody in the world to enjoy with anybody they want. Awaken your dreamer and find the treasure that is Battlelund.

Ready to smile? Good! 
Battlelund is an exciting, fast-paced 15mm high fantasy wargame with a decidedly cute and whimsical nature. 
If the wackier, cheerier side of things appeals to you, as well as games involving strategy and choice, Battlelund has you covered! 
The game, by intention, is easy to learn and enjoy, but to be the true "bashy smashy master", well that's another story... So then, what's inside this adorable 85-page tome of wargaming goodness for all?


     Visuals: Full color! Tons of photos and cheery art detailing the Battlelund World, as well as the weaving scope of our Battlelund printable miniatures line!
     Setting: Fairy tale-styled impressions of the Battlelund World, Albrathia, with flavorful, fun quotes and snippets. 
     Rules: All the rules, spells, special abilities, game types, etc. Written in a fun, and very learnable way!
     Stats: Every unit, hero, engine, and creature of every army has their profile listed inside! All you need is right here!
     Battle Report: Not only an enjoyable read, but a fun demonstration in motion!
     Resources: Tutorials on assembly of miniatures and base covers, as well as storage and the like! Also, reference document for ease of play.


Simply put, Battlelund is fun and cheer for everyone, perfect for both children and adults. Hear the trumpets blaring? That's the Battlelund World calling. See you in Albrathia!

—description from the publisher

Trézors is a luck based card game for 2-4 players. Each player starts with an identical hand of cards, playing through them over the course of the game. A row of treasures is revealed and all players play a card out of their hand simultaneously claiming a type of treasure. If only one player claims a type of treasure in the row, they win that treasure. If more than one player claim the same treasure the first to tap it with their finger wins it. Unclaimed treasures are discarded.

The game is over when there are no more "chest” cards. The players count the number of stars present on the cards won (with rarer treasures being worth more points) and, if needed, subtract a point per "hook" card drawn. The one with the most value points wins the game.

Contents: 59 cards

This That & Everything: People card pack is the name-dropping party game that challenges players to describe people for their teammates. A random list of six items makes winning a challenge - so be ready to shout out this, that, and everything in between to earn the most points! This card game includes exclusive content not included in the big box game and it can be played on its own or as a supplementary pack.

The Dungeons & Dragons: Adventure Begins co-operative board game is a fast entry into the world of D&D.

In the game, players choose their characters, then journey through the lands of Neverwinter, working together to overcome fantastic obstacles, battle monsters, and defeat the Boss monster terrorizing the realm. The role of Dungeon Master passes from player to player with each turn, so everyone gets to be part of the storytelling.

—description from the publisher

ElevatorUp is the brand NEW kid-created, kid-designed, kid-marketed, and kid-shipped (yes, they're all me) card game! Elevator Up will keep you smiling through Ups, Downs, and even getting Stuck!

ElevatorUp is fast-paced, easy-to-learn, and never gets old. Uno, GoFish, and other classic card games begin to become monotonous. Luckily, ElevatorUp provides a much needed innovation.

It is perfect for Travel, Camp, Sleepovers, Parties, Game-Nights, and any other occasion for a card game.

THEME:
An elevator going Up, Down, and sometimes Stuck in a building!

HOW TO PLAY:
Object - Be the first one out of cards.

Setup - Give each player 3 cards face down on the table (no one is allowed to look at these), 2 cards face up on the table (everyone can see these), and 3 cards for their hand (only that player can look at those).

Gameplay -  There are three sections of the game: Beginning: Hand Cards, Middle: Face Up Cards, End: Face Down Cards.
When it is your turn, you must discard a card that is either an equal/higher floor than the previously played card or a special card. If there is no previously played card, then you can play any card. Continue taking turns and discarding cards until someone does not have a special card or an equal/higher floor, meaning they must pick up the entire discard pile and add it to their hand. Players must keep at least 3 cards in their hand at all times, replenishing from the remainder of the deck. The special cards, including New Building, Stuck, Penthouse, Door Closed, and Down to the Lobby, throw exciting twists and turns.
Once the deck has been completely used up and players finish playing the cards in their hand, they move onto the face up cards, leaving them for all to see. The rules are the same for this section, but their hand can be seen by other players. Once they've gotten rid of their face up cards, it is time to play their face down cards. When it is their turn, the player will flip a card onto the discard pile. If it is an equal/higher floor or a special card, then shout "YAY" or any other celebratory exclamation. If it does not, then put on your game face and pick up the entire discard pile, adding it to your hand. The first player out of cards WINS!

description from publisher

Vampire: The Masquerade Rivals Expandable Card Game puts you in control of a coterie of vampires who vie for control of the city of San Francisco. Through dominating mortals, using their political influence, and clashing with their rivals in the streets in the dark of the night, you'll gather your allies and face off against one or more other players as you seek to push your agenda.

In Vampire: The Masquerade Rivals Expandable Card Game, each player plays with a Deck of Cards featuring a Clan from Vampire: The Masquerade Lore.

At the beginning of each player's turn, a new challenge or objective will be revealed in the streets. Each player gets two actions on their turn such as draw or play cards, recruit vampires, claim a title, or attack! The other clans will oppose you for dominance in the streets or directly in haven.

Defeat your rival, or gain 13 Agenda Points to win the game and claim dominance over San Francisco.

-description from publisher

The Complete Edition contains Murano, Murano: Promo Cards and Murano: The Christmas Tree packaged inside the box.

About the game:

Murano the game is set in Murano, a small group of seven islands near Venice that's well-known by tourists for its glassmaking. As in Venice, the islands of Murano are separated by canals, so gondolas and transportation are at the heart of this game.

The game board depicts the islands of Murano, with the islands being divided up into building sites and walkways. Surrounding the islands is a series of action spaces, with gondolas being present in some number of them at the start of play. On a turn, you move one of the gondolas in the direction of play to an empty space, then take the action shown there. You can't pass another gondola while moving or land in an occupied space, but for a coin you can move a gondola that's in front of the gondola you want to move, and you can pay to move multiple gondolas, if needed.

Some actions place shops on the islands, with shops coming in different types. You mark a shop to show ownership, and when tourists show up later, they will shop at various stores depending on their proximity and the goods they offer. You also need to take actions to move your personal gondolas to islands so that you can take actions there.

Why are you doing all of this activity? To score victory point cards in hand, and actions on the board will let you gain additional VP cards to give you direction to your actions or let you profit from what you've already done.

You can also use some of the buildings to create glassworks, and those glassworks come into play on the VP cards, through tourist sales, and via an action space shown at the bottom of the game board image that lets you sell different types of glass for money.

Everyone knows it: a typo in a text message and suddenly the whole content changes. Really annoying! But if you are already experienced in interpreting incorrect messages, you will score well in this communication game! Because this game requires imagination and eloquence.
Who can generate the most valid words by changing, removing, or adding just one letter from a wrong typed word?

There are 300 interesting quiz questions through the topics of pop culture, politics, science, sports, geography, everyday life and history of Germany.
Prove that you are a real Germany-expert!

This is how it's played: 
Answer the questions and get points for the right answer. 
The less help you need for the right answer, the more points you can get. When you get points you may move your character on the scoreboard. Whoever reaches the goal first, wins.

Highway 375 is a competitive car racing game for 2-6 players. Take on the role of vintage Hot Rod enthusiasts in a race around the infamous Area 51 in Nevada, along the stretch of road known as The Extraterrestrial Highway. The game features hand management, movement cards and checkpoints along with a challenge stage in the form of a drag racing strip. Players must balance their inventory of Food, Fuel and Money as they travel the circuit and compete for the prize. Featuring licensed brands such as STP, Moroso and Crane Cams, with a vintage styling to give the game a classic feel.

—description from the designer

How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party. This version of the black stories includes 50 cards with riddles about deadly Christmas.

The successful mystery series "Black Stories" is also available in the "scary-free" version - for families with children from 8 years old. Instead of dark and scary it gets colorful and funny at the "Black Stories Junior".

"Black stories junior: Rätselhafte Weihnachten" is a very special advent calendar. There are 24 riddles to shorten the time until Christmas. The players try to reconstruct the winter secrets by asking, guessing and fiddling about.

IQ FILES is a ESCAPE ROOM card game.

It consists in 3  adventures where 5-6 character are met in a room, without knowing each other, they will have to find the Exit, resolving several kind of tests: logical, deduction, jigsaw. But be careful!! they can die while they are trying to find the way out!!

There are more than 90 cards in each adventure.

Each card have also a combination number so you can combine any two cards (objects, characters) and see what happen.

The game mixes several kind of mechanics and keep the players in suspense till the end of the game.

Although you can play alone, it's easier to play with more people to help each other.

Each adventure has a difficulty level from 1 to 10.

Each game takes from 90 to 120 minutes and there are 2 ways of playing.


     Play with chronometer: game ends when time runs up (90 minutes).
     Play with no chronometer: we really suggest this way as you will enjoy better what's happening in the adventure .


Adventure 1: LIBERACIÓN Difficulty 4/10

Adventure 2: PECADOS Difficulty 6/10

Adventure 3: AMNESIA Difficulty 8/10

All these 3 adventures are independent games.

—description from the publisher

There are those that say, if you find yourself somewhere between myth and fantasy, and if you're really lucky (and high), you might be fortunate enough to discover GanjaLand.

How To Play.

     Everyone smokes, passing to the left (according to GanjaLand tradition). Once the circle is complete. use the same order to take turns for the game.
     The first person pulls a card from the deck and follows the card instructions, moving their character accordingly.
     That turn is over and the used card is discarded and placed back in the box.
     The game continues with each player/team drawing a new card from the deck.
     The first player to land on the specified tile will win and be pronounced the King/Queen of GanjaLand, and can be referred to as his or her high-ness.

Marching in rows, hoplites from Sparta and Athens fight each other on a vaste plain. Whoever manages to outflank the enemy or sneak into their line will bring havoc!
A themed version of Apit-Sodok.

—description by the designer

Published on History Kids, italian edition, issue #3.

Published by a car paint manufacturer, all players compete to be the best car paint garage. On his turn, a player may choose 1 of 3 options: 

     Buy up to 2 investment or cooperation tiles or perfomance stars
     Roll the die and move one of the 4 cars on the board track and - according to the space landed on - draw a mission card, an action card, an event card or do nothing. The mission cards give rewards, the more, the better you meet the required conditions (have stars and the right tiles). 
     Play an action card against an opponent.


If a player has completed his garage table with 6 investment tiles, 3 cooperation tiles and 6 perfomance stars, the game ends. The player with the most valuable garage wins.

Produced by Ravensburger Freizeit- und Promotion Service.

—user summary

A gambling game created to be used inside of fantasy role playing games as a plot hook, but it can also be played as a stand alone game.

The game uses six custom metal four-sided dice, each showing two blanks, one x, and one double x.  Players roll all the dice, re-rolling single x's until all dice are blank or double x.  Then the blanks are discarded, and the player makes one final roll with the remaining dice to find out of they multiply their winnings or lose it all.

The game is weighted in favor of the player.

Snekagon is a 7-turn abstract perfect information game about building snakes.

The goal of the game is to create a snake longer than your opponent by placing tiles of various shapes.

On your turn, you can place one tile either so that it doesn't touch any other tile, thus creating a new snake. The other option is to place the tile so that it touches some of your other tiles - this way, you make one of your snakes grow. You can even connect two of your snakes this way!

The players are reporters and want to collect 8 articles for their newspaper. On your turn, you throw 2 dice. The colored die determines what kind of card you are entitled to draw onto your hand.  Blue cards show  a specific department, grew ones a specific action like swap cards, play a department card from your hand into your display, make a revealed card of an opponent a canard (worthless), decide to accelerate before throwing the dice. The regular die determines the number of spaces you advance on the track.

You may play one action card on your turn. When you have 8 cards in your display, try to reach the space of the head quarter. After someone arrived there, all players add the value of their cards in their display and deduct the number of spaces they need to reach the headquarter. Highest score wins.

There are several German newspapers that published this game idea.

The game is produced by Ravensburger Freizeit- und Promotion-Service GmbH.

November…1942. World War 2 ravages the globe in a bloody conflict for the very soul of humankind. Across the war-torn regions of the Mediterranean, the Axis powers of Germany and Italy control much of the theater. But the mighty nations of the United States and Great Britain are on the move, launching a massive offensive — code-named Operation Torch.  But where will the secret Allied fleet choose to land its assault? Will they reclaim air superiority, control the sea, and gain a foothold in the underbelly of Axis-held Europe, or will Axis forces repel the Allies back in a storm of blood and fire?

Song for War: Mediterranean Theater is a tabletop strategy game based in the contested regions of southern Europe, north Africa, and the Mediterranean Sea during World War 2. Representing one of four nations, players must work together as the Allies (US or Great Britain) or Axis (Germany or Italy). Players have the option to set strategy, move units, attack and defend as individual nations or simultaneously as the Allied or Axis team. Innovative mechanics allow players to deploy their land, sea, and air units strategically as combined forces, with faster units moving first and more often, followed by heavy units with stronger firepower. Take strategic objectives, control shipping lanes and resupply, deploy new technologies and units, and recreate historical events to defeat the enemy and win the day.

SFW is an open-ended sandbox game of decisions, trade-offs, and teamwork. Multiple scenarios allow players to rewrite the pages of World War II history and win the day.

—description from the designer

As an up-and-coming paleontologist, your goal is to excavate fossils and sell them to museums. Combine small and large fossils of different types into a variety of prehistoric creatures. You begin with a novice dig team but can purchase additional dig teams and tool upgrades. As you uncover fossils and assemble them into creatures, your fame will increase.

This game primarily focuses on set collection but incorporates some basic engine-building elements.

The second edition comes in a smaller box, has upgraded components, and features more streamlined play.

—description from the designer
See who is champ! Square off with your opponent for an exciting bout. Punches, jabs, hooks, knock-outs, low punches - they are all in the cards of this exciting, easy-to-play boxing card game.

25 villains have escaped from jail and you have to recapture them in the Marvel Super Heroes DVD game!
Join your favorite super heroes like the Incredible Hulk, the Fantastic Four and more in a race against time! You'll have fun as you capture villains, jump from rooftop to rooftop and build a super hero! Includes footage from such series as Spider-Man, the X-Men and more!

"Whats' wrong with this sentence?

"If the misplaced apostrophe flew right up your nose, tis is the game for you.  Based on Dreyer's English, the New York Times best seller by Random House copy chief Benjamin Dreyer, STET! will help you sharpen your language skills or give you a reason to show them off."

The game includes 100 sentence cards.

—description from the box

You are in a bay surrounded by 3 sharks with your opponent. Only one of you will survive. Each turn you draw a card to complete 1 of 3 actions. You can either move your player, move a shark of your choice, or set up shelter with a sandbar. However, beware as each shark possesses a special ability! While sandbars may provide protection for now, they are not guaranteed to remain. In order to survive you will need the tactics to both evade the sharks and outwit your opponent into being the tasty treat.

—description from the designer

In Senate the Argument Game, you are a senator in the esteemed Roman senate. Think up the most mischievous Propositions for your peers to act out. But be careful, arguing and getting your way in the Senate requires quick wit and strategy.

As any good senator, you must use your Influence to acquire new arguments on the start of every round. The goal is to end up as on the winning team at the end of the round by Objecting arguments or Supporting those who are already winning. The round starts when a Senator makes a Proposition and ends when the senator who started the round plays their eighth turn. Everyone on the losing team must then act out the Proposition. The game ends when every senator has had the chance to make one Proposition.

Members of the winning and losing teams switch frequently throughout the round and Influence keeps changing hands due to yours and other senators' actions, so manage your arguments well. Betrayal, deception, and even begging - everything goes when reputations are at stake.

description from designer

Dungeon Coin is a microgame game that fits on a coin.

Game presentation:

     The player is exploring a dungeon in order to find gems.
     He tries to dodge fights with monsters.
     The game is short but the tension is high.


The rules are directly written on the 2 sides of the coin:

     Heads - Flip the coin and see your destiny. You find a monster = you lose the game.
      Tails - Flip the coin and see your destiny. You find a gem. Having 3 gems = victory.


—description from the designer

Sal & Pólvora (Salt & Gunpowder) is a Naval wargame system focused on the Age of Navigation, 1750-1825

Scale:
1 hex= 20 m
ship = 1/600 - 1/1200

Sequence of play:

     Wind adjustment
     Initiative
     Movements
     Shooting
     Boarding
     Repairs
     Moral


Contains ships data for France, Britain and Spain

- User description

Sommify is a blind wine-tasting board game. Players take turns guessing mystery wines in an atmosphere reminiscent of a drinking game, all while accidentally learning how to blind taste like a Sommelier. Players guess the Grape and Country of the mystery wine using the incredibly simple Sommify method on The Sommify Wine Key.

Wine culture can be stuffy, pretentious, and intimidating. We created Sommify as a way to have fun with your friends while accidentally learning to blind taste like the Somms!

The Somm is the judge of the round and will reveal clues about the mystery wine. Players either bring a concealed wine and take turns being The Somm, or one player plays Permanent Somm and provides all mystery wines for the game.

Players unlock Cellar Doors on the board by using common wine characteristics (Acidity, Tannins, etc.) to move closer to the final Call Zone to declare the mystery wine to the world. Players score points by pre-calling the wine correctly as well as guessing the wine correctly on the board. After all rounds and wines, the point-leader has proven themselves to be the best blind taster in the universe, and may refer to themselves in the third person for the remainder of the evening (bonus points for using the "Royal We").

-description from designer

Horror Flick is an all vs one game where one player takes on the role of the antagonist and the rest of the players take on the part of camp counselors trying to rescue the campers and achieve a goal depending on the antagonist.

The counselors will be moving to locations constructed by the antagonist to find and build up a simple engine to help them to deal with the problems that arise. Players can fight, hide, search, and run as basic actions.  Each player has variable powers and items further the things they can do.

The antagonist will construct the search decks at the locations laying traps and surprises to get the players.  Then during game play will move around targeting players trying to complete a goal based off of the antagonist they chose at game start. Each antagonist has different actions they can do.

The winning condition for both sides is based off of which antagonist the player chooses.  It could be find key items to escape, rescuing a number of campers, performing a ritual, and the list goes on.  Just think of any campy horror flick and how it resolves.

—description from the designer

This is an abstract puzzle game that plays 2 to 4 players where the players manipulate the board in order to get their pieces closest to the goal before the game ends.

—description from the designer

Orcs on the Horizon pits you against an onrush of Orc hordes.  Mine silver to pay for upgrades to your archers, knights, and fortress while the hordes march towards you. Build up your archers to take out the orcs before they make it to your fortress.  Or, build up the defenses of your fortress to deal with the orcs that do get there.  Or, build up your knights to battle the orcs that make it into your fortress.  Do a little of each, or all of one, or some other combination to defeat the orc horde.

Orcs on the Horizon is a solo, one card, adventurous, dice based combat game played in two phases.  In phase 1, as Orc hordes march towards your fortress, mine silver to purchase upgrades to your Archers, Knights, or Fortress.  Archers can attack Orcs around the midpoint of their march towards your fortress.  Once the Orcs reach your fortress, flip the card and begin phase 2.  In phase 2, Archers aren't used, only Knights and the defenses of your fortress.  Battle the Orcs to the death to win the game.

The game was created for the 2020 1 Card Print and Play Design Contest.

-description from designer

Don’t Call Them Bugs!

Listen up newbie! I know what you unwarranted high regard for yourself recruits call our enemy – Bugs. A bug is something very small you see crawling on the ground. Something insignificant that you step on and keep doing whatever you’re doing. I got news for you. That’s not what these things, these Bugs, are. We’re going down into the Tunnels looking for real Bugs. When you meet one face to face, try not to wet yourself, and pray to whatever god you believe in that you get out alive. Because to them; we’re the insignificant ones.

5150: Bugs – No Retreat is the second of three books linked together to cover the Bug infestation that threatens the 5150 Universe. All three are stand-alone games. In fact, 5150: Bugs –No Retreat can be used with all of our other 5150 titles.

What: Sci-Fi Squad/Platoon size combat.
Scale: Man to man combat. 1 figure equals 1 man or Bug.
Your Role: Players can command from one Squad to a full Platoon of infantry.
Playability: Designed for solo, same side and head to head play.
5150: Bugs - No Retreat can be played in a variety of ways:

     You can play as a Squad Leader with a full Squad.
     You can play as a Squad Leader with less than a full Squad.
     You can play as a Platoon Leader with a full Platoon of multiple Squads.


The bottom line is you can play it any way you like, with any figures you may already have or with the included color counters.

Inside you’ll find:

     A man to man skirmish combat system that plays fast and yields realistic results.
     Complete rules covering five types of Bugs – Warrior, Worker, Flyer, Puker, Queen and Brain.
     Color Counters including Fort 373.
     Ten different Scenarios that are linked together, building your Story.
     Sixteen different Lists covering seven different Factions for you to choose from.
     A minimal bookkeeping Campaign System that gives meaning to every game as the results of one will affect the outcome of the next.


Surrounded? So what!

Word’s come down from the top. The Bugs are on a roll and moving fast towards us. We’re cut off from any support so we need to pull back to Fort 373. Once there, we hold the fort and buy HQ some time to regroup. With any luck, they’ll send someone to pick us up, but don’t count on it. Doesn’t matter anyway, we just have to do our job. 
Do…your…job!

—description from the publisher
Take on the role of a teen trying to protect an alien life form that crashed down from other aliens that came after it.  The game is a cooperative action point based game.

Firville is about to change! The mayor of this cosy town has just ordered a new suburban district – Little Firville.
The key to the plan is to develop the centre of the new district, which at the moment is full of sad empty parcels.

Become a member of one of four animal families and plan the building of the new district. Assign tasks to the residents of your quarter, send your representative to the bulding site, perform actions and earn materials.
Before the game ends you will need to have proven cunning in order to earn as many winning points as possible.

'Little Firville' is a family game on economy based on the worker placement mechanics.

A  fun-filled strategy game full of intrigue and betrayal set in Henry VIII´s court. Use your cunning to undermine and weaken your rival queens by spreading ridiculous rumours to ruin their reputation - anything to be the King´s favourite and win the crown!

—description from the box

In the game, you are one of Henry VIII's queens who intrigues to become the one Henry VIII will marry. In turn, you roll the dice and go into one of the castle rooms to try to win a trophy poll based on different traits. For each traits you have the most in gives you a trophy token. You win these by either taking from other players who are in the same room as you or playing gossip cards that lower other players' values.
You win either by having at least three trophy tokens and reaching the same place as Henry VIII. You can also win if you are the last remaining queen in the game (other queens can be eliminated if any of their traits end up at too low a level).

—user summary

How could that have happened? Black Stories are fiddly, morbid and mysterious riddles for teenagers and adults. The players try to reconstruct the crime by asking, guessing and fiddling about. Only yes/no answers are allowed. A spooky card game just right for any party.

"Black stories: Tödliche Weihnachten" is a very special advent calendar. There are 24 riddles to shorten the time until Christmas.

1612 A.D. – In a bustling, fishy dock somewhere on the east coast of the American continent, settlers’ ships bring vast amount of goods to the New World. There is a lot to do before the ships can set sail again.
–    Listen up, lazy gang! No rest until the ship is unloaded! Pack those boxes tight, we have lots of stuff! Hurry up and move it! The Governor may arrive any minute!

In DOCK you play as settlers of the New World, tasked by the Governor to manage a warehouse. Different boxes are arriving from the ships. Can you load them more tightly than others to satisfy the Governor? Your efforts will be greatly rewarded with silver.

DOCK is roll and write game for up to 10 players and a solo mode for one player. You draw rectangles on a checkered playing area and try to fit them as tight as possible. The 2 dice shows the two side length of the boxes to be drawn.

—description from the designer

Goal 10 is a card game that simulates a football match. In turn, you attack the player to your left using an attack card. That player can try to defend himself by playing a defense card otherwise it will be a goal. Attacking players take one goal card and the one who has first collected five goal cards wins. In the deck, there are also special cards such as Offside, VAR and more. Two decks can be combined to allow up to 10 players to join.

Many events in American history have been labeled "trials of the century", but for a young nation, it would have been impossible to top United States v. Aaron Burr. Unlike Washington, Jefferson, Madison or Hamilton, Aaron Burr came from American royalty — a founding father descended from the original puritanical stock that arrived in Plymouth. His father was the second president of Princeton. His grandfather was Jonathan Edwards, the philosopher-theologian who wrote "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God," perhaps the most important American literary work of its time.

So in 1776, if you were going to identify any of the Founders who would later stand trial for treason to his country, Aaron Burr would be the least likely — yet Burr's journey as an enormous talent born under a dark star is now well known. Less well understood is that when he shot Alexander Hamilton in the early morning hours of July 11, 1804, it would set in motion a chain of events much more bizarre than anything depicted on Broadway.

Aaron Burr never stood trial for killing Alexander Hamilton in a duel. His trial was for treason, three years later, at the insistence of the Thomas Jefferson, the man Burr had narrowly lost to in the contested election of 1800. An embittered and politically ruined Burr seemed to have developed a scheme to separate the new Louisiana Purchase territories from the United States and declare himself king over the new entity. When Jefferson learned of the plot, he ordered Burr's arrest and publicly declared him guilty of treason.

United States v. Aaron Burr: The Treason Trial of America's Third Vice President, a card-driven game for two players, recreates the treason trial of Aaron Burr in Richmond in 1807. But by accident of recent judicial reforms, Thomas Jefferson's detested cousin, Chief Justice John Marshall, would be riding circuit and would preside over the case. The resulting legal contest would read like a list of who's who of America's Founding Fathers.

United States vs. Aaron Burr is a fast-playing card-driven game in which players seek to use events, evidence, and witnesses of Burr's activities to convince a jury to return a guilty verdict — or if playing for the defense, persuade at least one juror to find Aaron Burr not guilty. Each round, players have the opportunity to question witnesses, persuade jurors, and make points of law to the Chief Justice which will aid them in their cause. The game highlights all the events and participants surrounding one of the most important trials in American Constitutional Law — setting the precedent that the President of the United States is NOT immune from legal court orders, a precedent very much cited by the Supreme Court today.

So try your hand as a great litigator in a great trial. Perhaps you will even find yourself smiling more and talking less!

Izayoi (åå…­å¤œå°ç”º) is a board game where players race to collect 16 types of wakomono and compete for points. The game is for 3 to 5 people and it can be played in 15 minutes.

One player places a recommendation card on the field.  Depending on the number of votes one of the players will earn the wakomono.  There are also some unique rules, and it also requires strict hand management. Players aim for the highest score, but they should not exceed their master's score. Eventually, if a player's score exceeds his/her master's, the player will be dropped from the game. This mirrors Japanese culture in which one should be “polite” and not make the master lose face.

Every spring, the cherry trees blossom all over Japan. The Japanese celebrate this occasion, as according to their traditions the goddess of Fuji mountain, Konohana Sakuya Hima, revives the fallen flowers at this time. The cherry flower is a symbol of vitality called "sakura".

The players in Sakura aim to play cards without taking any hands. They have to play two cards each time, one on each side of the Jin-Jang card following the rules, which by default require higher number on the Jin side and lower on the Jang side in the same color. (Alternatively, a player can place the same number in any color.) Also, the players are aided in their success by several characters, who require payment (money). The game ends when everyone has only two cards left in their hand. The player who earns the fewest points wins the favor of the goddess and glory will be theirs until next spring.


This edition contains previous Kickstarter extras (not exclusive).

Four factions of warriors battle to survive on a doomed land that will be destroyed piece by piece, taking its occupants with it. You must strategize to survive—by fleeing, fighting or sacrificing your weakest members—whatever you must do to be the last one left standing when the land around you has been annihilated.

Be the last one standing in a strategic fight to survive The Final Battle Royale!

•On each turn, you can move three spaces and/or battle an opponent.
•Watch as the Event Tracker counts down to the removal of one of the game board zones—get out before you lose members of your faction or choose to sacrifice those pieces.
•When a zone is removed, a new Card is turned over to indicate the next zone to be removed.
•Use Power Stones to make more moves or help win battles.
•When you land in a space on the Game Board next to another player’s faction member, you can choose to battle. 
•To battle, each player involved rolls their Battle Die. The value they rolled, plus the value of their faction member, is their battle power. The player with the highest battle power wins the battle. The losing piece is removed from the Game Board.

The last player with a faction member(s) left on the Game Board is the winner of The Final Battle Royale!

-description from publisher

Lachen, Lachen, Lachen is a party game, there are question cards and answer cards, both stacks are shuffled, the top question card is read aloud and then the top answer card is read, the fun lies in the comic of the combinations.

If the cards have the same color, they are put out of play, but if they have different colors, they are placed in a pile in front of the person who answered the question. The game continues until someone gets rid of all the cards.

—user summary
